definitions.definition: the feeling that somebody/something is without value and deserves no respect at all
definitions.sensetop: with contemptbeneath contemptin contemptcontempt for somebody/something

examples.text: She looked at him with contempt.
I shall treat that suggestion with the contempt it deserves.
His treatment of his children is beneath contempt *(= so bad that it is not even worth feeling  for)*.
Politicians seem to be generally **held in contempt** by ordinary people.
They had shown a contempt for the values she thought important.
His remarks betray a staggering contempt for the truth *(= are completely false)*.
He has a deep contempt for racists.
His remarks betray an utter contempt for the truth.
She looked at him with barely disguised contempt.
He did not want to risk the contempt of his fellows.
I felt nothing but contempt for her.

definitions.definition: a lack of worry or fear about rules, danger, etc.

examples.text: The firefighters showed a contempt for their own safety.
She'd developed what she considered a healthy contempt for authority.

definitions.definition: the crime of refusing to obey an order made by a court; not showing respect for a court or judge

examples.text: He could be jailed for two years for contempt.
She was held in contempt for refusing to testify.

definitions.definition: knowing somebody/something very well may cause you to lose respect for them/it

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin contemptus, from contemnere, from con- (expressing intensive force) + temnere ‘despise’.
